items.abstract:
<jats:p>The outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria is a biological structure with a unique composition that significantly contributes to the survival of bacteria in the unfavorable conditions of the host organism. The lipopolysaccharide constitutes about 70% of the external part of the outer membrane. The LPS molecule is composed of three different parts: lipid A, core oligosaccharide and O antigen. Despite the O-specific antigen being one of the most intensely studied surface structures of bacterial polysaccharides, a number of questions regarding the mechanism of the O antigen biosynthesis and its transport to the cell surface are still unanswered. The paper describes the biosynthesis of the lipopolysaccharide molecule, with particular emphasis on the O-specific chain biosynthesis, the mechanism of lipopolysaccharide length regulation and the influence of the type of synthesized O-specific chains on bacterial survival in adverse host organisms.

</jats:p>
title: Biosynthesis of lipopolysaccharides with different length of the O-specific region as a virulence factor of Gram-negative bacteria

items.abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
				<jats:p> The mode of membrane attachment of the Rieske iron -sulfur proteins from cytochrome b<jats:sub>6</jats:sub>ƒ complex of pea thylakoids and from cytochrome bc<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> complex of yeast mitochondria has been studied using biochemical approaches.</jats:p>
				<jats:p>The relative sensitivity of the Rieske protein to trypsin in the thylakoid membrane shows that all trypsin sites of the Rieske protein are on the lumen side of the thylakoid membrane. In contrast to cytochrome / the chloroplast Rieske protein was extracted from thylakoids using chaotropic agents (NaSCN, urea), an alkaline pH and relatively low concentrations of Trinon X-100. The cytochrome bc<jats:sub>1</jats:sub> complex Rieske protein from mitochondrial membranes of yeast was also released by NaSCN and alkaline treatment.</jats:p>
				<jats:p>The results presented here led us to the conclusion, that the mitochondrial and chloroplast Rieske proteins are extrinsic and that their association with the rest of the complex involves hydrophobic interactions.</jats:p>
title: Membrane Association of the Rieske Iron-Sulfur Protein
subject: General Biochemistry, Genetics and Molecular Biology

title: Branched-chain and aromatic amino acid plasma concentration as a markers of metabolic syndrome

items.abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
				<jats:p> The present paper explains in a descriptive way the findings and derivations, concerning the various needs, solutions and priorities which are identified in existing urban building envelopes of Poland, especially in Rzeszow housing estates.</jats:p>
title: The Problem and Needs of Existing Urban Multifamily Building Estates in Poland

items.abstract: <jats:title>Synopsis</jats:title><jats:p>We show that the linear viscous damping Δ<jats:italic>u</jats:italic><jats:sub>t</jats:sub>, is so strong that it altogether prevents propagation of singularities of the gradient of solutions to the system of viscoelasticity. Moreover, no creation or annihilation of singularities is possible in finite time.</jats:p>
title: The viscous damping prevents propagation of singularities in the system of viscoelasticity

items.abstract: <jats:title>Synopsis</jats:title><jats:p>We study the equations of viscoelasticity in a multidimensional setting for the ‘no-traction’ boundary data. For the sake of modelling phase transitions we do not assume elliptieity of the stored energy function W. We construct dynamics in W<jats:sup>1,2</jats:sup>(Ωℝ<jats:sup>n</jats:sup>) globally in time. Next, we study the question of stability for a class of equilibria. Moreover, we show a certain kind of decay in time of solutions for arbitrary initial conditions.</jats:p>
title: Dynamical modelling of phase transitions by means of viscoelasticity in many dimensions
